ray.rage.asset

Interface AssetManager<T extends Asset>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - A generic type that extends the asset interface.
    All Superinterfaces:
    Disposable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractAssetManager, AnimationManager, MaterialManager, MeshManager, ShaderManager, SkeletonManager, TextureManager

    public interface AssetManager<T extends Asset>
extends Disposable
    An asset manager is responsible for handling the assets and their life-cycle. Some of these assets include meshes, textures, materials, and others types that may be added in the future.

    Note that a manager is not responsible for loading a particular asset. Rather, it relies on concrete asset-loaders to do this work, thus, decoupling the role of managing the life-cycle of a asset from knowledge about its internal storage format.

    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera
    See Also:
    Asset, AssetLoader

        Returns:

      • getAsset

        T getAsset(java.nio.file.Path path)
    throws java.io.IOException
        Gets an asset identified by the file system path, creating a new instance the first time it's requested.

        If it needs to be created, then the appropriate asset-loader is automatically determined based on the file extension. If the asset at the specified path has already been created, then the asset-manager returns the pre-existing asset instead of re-creating it.

        Parameters:
        path - The file system path this asset will be loaded from.
        Returns:
        The asset.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If this asset-manager cannot find the asset at the specified path
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If this asset-manager does not have an asset-loader capable of loading the asset.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the path is empty.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the path is null.

      • getAssetByPath

        T getAssetByPath(java.lang.String path)
          throws java.io.IOException
        Gets a asset identified by the file system path as a string, creating it if it does not yet exist.

        If it needs to be created, then the appropriate AssetLoader is automatically determined based on common file extensions. If the asset at the specified path has already been created, then the manager is expected to return the pre-existing asset instead of re-creating it.

        Parameters:
        path - A string specifying the file system path this asset will be loaded from.
        Returns:
        The asset.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If this asset-manager cannot find the asset at the specified path, or does not have a AssetLoader capable of loading it.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If this asset-manager does not have an asset-loader capable of loading the asset.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the path string is empty.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the path string is null.

      • getAssetByName

        T getAssetByName(java.lang.String name)
        Gets an existing asset with the specified name.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the asset to search for.
        Returns:
        The asset with the specified name.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the name is empty.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If this asset-manager does not currently own a asset with the specified name.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the name is null.

      • createManualAsset

        T createManualAsset(java.lang.String name)
        Creates a new asset instance using the specified name.

        A manual asset is one that is not loaded from the file system using an AssetLoader. Instead, it's created in an ad-hoc way, allowing the clients to create assets arbitrarily.

        Note that this will always create a new instance. It's offered purely for convenience and practical purposes.

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the new asset.
        Returns:
        The asset.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the name is empty.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If a manual asset by the specified name already exists.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the name is null.

      • hasAsset

        boolean hasAsset(java.nio.file.Path path)
        Checks whether this asset-manager already knows about the asset identified by the given path.
        Parameters:
        path - The path where the asset would've been loaded from.
        Returns:
        True if the asset is already loaded. False otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the path is empty.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the path is null.

      • hasAssetByPath

        boolean hasAssetByPath(java.lang.String path)
        Checks whether this asset-manager already knows about the asset identified by the given path, as a string.
        Parameters:
        path - The path, as a string, where the asset would've been loaded from.
        Returns:
        True if the asset is already loaded. False otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the path string is empty.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the path string is null.

        Returns:
        True if the asset is already loaded. False otherwise.

        The number of loaded assets.

      • removeAsset

        void removeAsset(Asset asset)
        Requests that this manager stop managing a asset.

        Note that this simply removes the asset from this manager's ownership, but does not explicitly cause the asset to be disposed. It's up to the client to manually manage the asset to avoid it getting garbage-collected if all other references go out of scope.

        Parameters:
        asset - The asset to be removed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the asset is null.

      • removeAssetByPath

        void removeAssetByPath(java.lang.String pathString)
        Requests that this manager stop managing a asset by the specified file system path, as a string.

        Note that this simply removes the asset from this manager's ownership, but does not explicitly cause the asset to be disposed. It's up to the client to manually manage the asset to avoid it getting garbage-collected if all other references go out of scope.

        Parameters:
        pathString - The file system path, as a string, of the asset to remove.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the path string is empty.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the path string is null.

      • removeAssetByName

        void removeAssetByName(java.lang.String name)
        Requests that this manager stop managing a asset by the specified name.

        Note that this simply removes the asset from this manager's ownership, but does not explicitly cause the asset to be disposed. It's up to the client to manually manage the asset to avoid it getting garbage-collected if all other references go out of scope.

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the asset to remove.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the name string is empty.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the name is null.

      • removeAllAssets

        void removeAllAssets()
        Requests that this manager stop managing all its assets.

        Note that this simply removes the asset from this manager's ownership, but does not explicitly cause the asset to be disposed. It's up to the client to manually manage the asset to avoid it getting garbage-collected if all other references go out of scope. To explicitly destroy them, see Disposable.notifyDispose()

        See Also:
        Disposable.notifyDispose()

      • addAssetLoader

        void addAssetLoader(AssetLoader<T> loader)
        Adds a asset-loader to this manager.
        Parameters:
        loader - The asset-loader being added.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the asset-loader is null.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the asset-loader had already been added.

      • getAssetLoader

        AssetLoader<T> getAssetLoader(java.lang.Class<AssetLoader<T>> cls)
        Gets the asset-loader for the specified class.
        Parameters:
        cls - The class the asset-loader is responsible for loading.
        Returns:
        The asset-loader of the specified class, if available. Otherwise null.

      • getAssetLoaderCount

        int getAssetLoaderCount()
        Gets the number of asset-loaders currently available to this asset-manager.
        Returns:
        The number of asset-loaders.

      • removeAssetLoader

        void removeAssetLoader(java.lang.Class<AssetLoader<T>> cls)
        Removes the specified asset-loader from this manager, if one is found to match the specified class.

        A manager without an appropriate asset-loader will not be able to create new assets of the specified type until the required asset-loader is reinstated.

        Note that this simply removes the asset-loader from this manager. It does not cause the asset-loader to be explicitly destroyed.

        Parameters:
        cls - The class the asset-loader is responsible for loading.

      • removeAssetLoader

        void removeAssetLoader(AssetLoader<T> loader)
        Removes the specified asset-loader from this manager.

        A manager without an appropriate asset-loader will not be able to create new assets of the specified type until the required asset-loader is reinstated.

        Note that this simply removes the asset-loader from this manager. It does not cause the asset-loader to be explicitly destroyed. To explicitly destroy them, see Disposable.notifyDispose()

        Parameters:
        loader - The asset-loader to be removed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the asset-loader is null.
        See Also:
        Disposable.notifyDispose()

      • removeAllAssetLoaders

        void removeAllAssetLoaders()
        Removes all the asset-loaders from this manager.

        A manager without an appropriate asset-loader will not be able to create new assets of the specified type until the required asset-loader is reinstated.

        Note that this simply removes the asset-loader from this manager. It does not cause the asset-loader to be explicitly destroyed.
